prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife. Let me break it down.

First, the husband moved his office to the bedroom even though the basement was available. The wife suggested the basement for fewer disturbances, but he chose the bedroom because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so the wife has to manage the kids and avoid making noise. This limits her ability to do chores, take a shower, etc. She works from home too and handles most household tasks. She told him she can't guarantee silence in the bedroom but would in the basement. Now they're arguing about who's at fault.

The key points here are about mutual consideration and practical solutions. The husband's choice affects the wife's ability to work and manage the home. The basement was a viable option that would minimize disruptions. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a situation where the wife can't do her normal activities without disturbing him. The wife's stance is that she can't control others' noise in the bedroom, so she's not at fault for that. The husband is in a position where he could have chosen a less disruptive location but didn't. The wife is trying to balance her work and household duties, which are significant. 

I think the husband made a selfish choice by prioritizing his view over the wife's needs. The wife isn't at fault because she's trying to accommodate by offering the basement, which would solve the problem. The problem arises from his decision to stay in the bedroom. Therefore, the author (wife) isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
